Fields.DialogueText: Enemy ships due east!
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Capitaine! I have an important question for you.

Fields.MenuText: I told them not to do it! I was not an accomplice, I promise.
How important? Do I need to sit down before you ask the question?
Ask away.

Fields.DialogueText: ... I don't want to know. Wait... Ah, I see. Humor. Your timing is improving, for what it's worth.
It's probably more important to me than it is to you - and no, you can remain standing.
Merci.
I wanted to ask you about my showcase.
Fair enough. What would you like to know?
How did you like the event as a whole?
I thought it went really well. You were quite eloquent when you spoke in front of everyone.
What about everyone else? Were they bored? Did any of them not enjoy themselves?
So far I'm only hearing rave reviews, especially when it comes to your photographs.
Really? Which ones were their favorites?
The ones you took during battle. They loved what you were able to capture.
I knew that was a good idea!
That doesn't mean it still wasn't reckless.
Yes, yes, of course, Capitaine. Both of those things may be true.
Does that answer all of your questions?
Oui! It does! Thank you for your input.
You're very welcome. But, seriously, no more pictures during battle. No backsliding.
Eh, bien.
I've only now remembered something.
What would that be?
Something that has to do with you.
That doesn't sound good. What is it?
I gave you The Great Gatsby to read.
Oh, right. That.
How has it been going?

Fields.MenuText: I've finished it.

Fields.DialogueText: Have you, now? What was your favorite part?

Fields.MenuText: When Nick turned on Gatsby and shot him. I was completely shocked by that turn of events.
Um... probably when Daisy and Gatsby ended up getting married. I love a happy ending.
The scene where Nick saved Gatsby from drowning. It really strengthened their bond.

Fields.DialogueText: Hm. Nick shot Gatsby? I don't recall that.
That would have been a happy ending, had it actually happened.
Gatsby, who has his own pool, had to be saved from drowning? Interesting.
You haven't finished the book, have you?
I did read it back in the '20s. I just... haven't had as much time for the second go-around as I'd hoped.
Oh, but you need to make time! There aren't so many American authors I need to read in the original English, but Fitzgerald...
It's just so good. You'll be glad you got back into it, I promise!
I'll do some more reading tonight, I promise.
I'm happy to hear it. I'll be happier when we can argue over our readings.
Morganas inbound!
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: I've made essentially no progress whatsoever.

Fields.DialogueText: Capitaine!

Fields.MenuText: I read it back in the `20s. Haven't had much chance to dip back in lately.

Fields.DialogueText: I do believe that leaning against the ship railing whilst reading and smoking a cigarette is your most natural state, La Motte-Picquet.
Well, I do feel quite at ease, so I can't disagree with your assessment.
What are you reading this time around?
A Dorothy Sayers mystery.
English language again?
Mhm. I've just finished reading Émile Gaboriau's mysteries, and I was looking for a slightly different flavor.
Is the Sayers stuff proving to be worth your time?
It is. Did you want a smoke?
No, thank you.
How is The Great Gatsby coming along?
It's going well. When I have the time to read, I find the experience very enjoyable.
I knew you would. Who's your favorite character?

Fields.MenuText: Probably Nick. I think, in a lot of ways, the book is about him making sense of the world after the last war, and that... well, I get that.
I would say Gatsby, because he isn't afraid to keep loving someone. And because he throws the best parties.
Jordan seems like an interesting character. I wish she appeared in the story more often.

Fields.DialogueText: Ah. You have an affinity for the thoughtful observer. I should have known!
Some would say that is what makes him a naïve fool.
Yes, Jordan's character is an interesting one. So saucy... so mysterious.
It would seem you've passed the test. I'm glad you're enjoying the book. As soon as you finish, we'll have to set aside time to discuss.
I'm sure you'll love that.
I will indeed. There is nothing better than a spirited debate.
Not even a good cigarette?
*ALARM*
I know what I'm going to get when I roll one of these. When discussing literature...who can say?
@BATTLE
Are you finished? Have you finished?
Someone is excited.
Is it you? From having finished the book?
Yes, I have finished The Great Gatsby.
Formidable! Do you have time to discuss the story now?
I guess I have a little free time before my next meeting. What questions do you have for me?
What catches your interest? What are you turning over in your mind as you think about it?
I would have to say Gatsby's love for Daisy.
Really? Why?

Fields.MenuText: I think the determination he shows in pursuing the romance is inspiring, frankly.
The unhealthy parts of it seem very realistic to me.
One day, I want to love someone as much as Gatsby loved Daisy.

Fields.DialogueText: Personally, I wouldn't call it determination. Stupidity, perhaps.
That is true. Although I don't know what that says about Gatsby, that he would willingly subject himself to hurt over and over again.
Really? I think that would be foolish of you. It wouldn't do to blind yourself with that green light.
You certainly have some strong opinions about this book.
Of course I do. I have to form opinions when I read. Otherwise, the experience is lacking.
I can't argue with that.
Enemy ships inbound!
Don't think this discussion is over, Capitaine. We will finish at a later time.
I look forward to it.
@BATTLE
Capitaine, I have a proposition. A real one.

Fields.MenuText: Do I need to steal anything?
Do I need to kill anyone?
How much is it going to cost me?

Fields.DialogueText: Not unless you really want a book.
No, certainly not.
Very little, I should think.
All right. What is your proposition?
What would you say about joining me and a friend in our book swap group?
I don't know that I have any books to swap.
That's all right! We have plenty of books to share.
What would we do in this group? Other than... swap books, I guess.
Read and discuss, much as we did with The Great Gatsby.
I see. Do you mind if I take some time to think it over?
Not at all. I would never force you to do something you didn't want to do.
*ALARM*
Your candid shots say otherwise.
I need hardly remind you that you ultimately signed off on every one of them.
@BATTLE
That's different!
Did you enjoy our last conversation, Capitaine?
What do you mean?
Our most recent discussion of The Great Gatsby. Did you enjoy it?
It played out a little differently than the previous ones we'd had.
Well, I for one enjoyed it.

Fields.MenuText: I guess arguments can be somewhat invigorating.
Typically, I prefer my conversations to include less yelling.
You criticized everything I had to say about the book. You found that enjoyable?

Fields.DialogueText: I don't know that I'd describe that discussion as an argument. I viewed it more as a friendly debate!
Really? Was I yelling? You should have told me. My voice tends to get louder the more passionate I become.
I was only trying to challenge your thoughts. If you're going to maintain certain views, it's important to be certain of why you believe them.
I suppose that changes my perspective somewhat.
So you did enjoy it, after all?
That still might be a bit of a stretch. But I think I could learn to enjoy it, potentially.
If so... and I don't mean to push, but... then what do you say to joining my book swap?
Ah, so this is where all this has been headed.
It was inevitable, Capitaine. Embrace it.
All right, all right. I'll give it a try.
Really?
*ALARM*
Really. Now, come on. Let's get to work.
@BATTLE
Reading as always, even at a party.
Especially at a party. I will engage with it on my terms.
Is this book a part of your book swap?
Non. This one is for leisure.
How do you have time for that?
I can always make time for a good book. I don't know that I've ever read just one at a time.
When are we having the first book swap gathering?
Soon. I'll let you know the day...
Oh, no! The cake!
I've got it!
Oomph! There you go.
You caught it? Thank you so much!
Not a problem.
That was definitely something.
I almost dropped my camera once. Never again. A cake is not so different.

Fields.MenuText: You have quick reflexes, La Motte-Picquet. I barely had time to flinch before you rescued the cake.
You're certainly faster than any human I've seen.
I wish I could move around as quickly as you do.

Fields.DialogueText: I suppose you could say my reflexes are quicker than others'.
Thirty-three knots, Capitaine. Just using what they gave me at Lorient.
You'd be surprised. All it takes is something you simply cannot live without.
Whatever you say, La Motte-Picquet. You were quick and there is no denying it.
*ALARM*
How about we put that speed to good use?
@BATTLE
I enjoyed our book gathering earlier. We've got a good mix of perspectives.
Wonderful! I'm so pleased you decided to join us.
What was the title of our next book?
Murder in the Cathedral, by T.S. Eliot.
Ah, right. Thanks.
We'll have to get some more verse dramas in the future. I like the way they flow.
Noted. Anything else, Capitaine?
Actually, yes. I had a question.
Ask it! I am eager to learn.
Why do you love to read as much as you do?
Because I love travel. Reading allows me to do that.

Fields.MenuText: But reading is one of the most stationary activities you can do.
Have I been reading wrong this whole time?
Not physically, of course.

Fields.DialogueText: Maybe for your body, but not for your mind.
I'm reading the same as you are. I'm simply engaging my mind more.
Of course. But the physical realm is finite.
When I say travel, I mean mentally. Reading affords me a journey through the different worlds and eras stored within the pages of a book.
That's almost poetic, La Motte-Picquet.
Morganas approaching!
We should finish this discussion at our next book gathering.
I will take you with me on that journey. First stop: 1170, and an archbishop's untimely assassination...
@BATTLE
Why are you standing on the edge of the ship?
I'm sailing the waves of the ocean across the world.
Are you're sure it's safe to be holding your arms out like that?
If I fall off, I'll only float my way back to the ship.
Ah... yes. That's right.
Don't you love that nice breeze? The feel of the sun on your face?
It's pretty dreary outside today, La Motte-Picquet.  The sky is completely cloud-covered.
Are you telling me you don't see what I see?
Do I need to arrange a psychological examination for you?
Tread carefully, Capitaine. I am no lunatic, and it's rude of you to insinuate otherwise.
You will eventually. You simply need some practice. Maybe if you stand up here with me, you'll see as I see.
If I can't see it from down here, I won't be able to see it from up there.
Remember how we spoke about imagination?
Yes, you use it while you're reading.
And I also am using it now. I find using your imagination, especially on days like today, can help create a better outlook.
So since it's cloudy, you imagined a sunny day. I can see how that would help bring some positivity.
And we all need some positivity every now and again. Especially with those Morganas heading our way.
@BATTLE
Don't get me wrong. I wish I could see what you do.
Are you ready, Capitaine?
For what? Is there a battle headed our way?
Oui, but it's not here quite yet. I'm talking about the book. Murder in the Cathedral.
You're finished already?
Oui - and now it is your turn.
You should be warned, I don't read as fast as you.
I know. It took you forever to read The Great Gatsby, but that's okay. I won't judge. But that doesn't mean I'll let you off the hook if you procrastinate.

Fields.MenuText: I'm sure having you watching over my shoulder will be motivation enough.

Fields.DialogueText: Enemy ships headed in from the east!
Just the thing to tire me out for a read...
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: For a 200-page book I thought I'd be done quicker.
Ok, give me a hint...what should I be looking for?

Fields.DialogueText: Yours to decide, Capitaine. I wouldn't dream of coloring your perspective with mine until you've had time to develop one.
It'd certainly make for some nice candid shots.
Life interrupts us all in what we'd rather be doing. You will find no reproach from me.
When I finish, you'll be the first to know.
What are you doing, Capitaine?
Look what we have here. If it isn't the Capitaine, reading. I just have to take a few photographs.
*readies camera, aims, photographs*
Huh? What are you doing with that camera, La Motte-Picquet?
Wouldn't you like to know...

Fields.MenuText: I hope you weren't taking a photograph of me.
Did you take a photograph of me?
I hope you got my good side.

Fields.DialogueText: It's so seldom I see you completely relaxed. Wouldn't you like a memento?
Maaaaaaybe.
You'll be the first one to know. I got a few great shots, so you shouldn't have anything to worry about.
How long were you standing here, before you took the photographs?
Not too long, but you were too engrossed in the book to notice.
Damn. That's not ideal behavior from the captain of a warship.
Ah, but you're off duty, and you can trust that I would come collect you in case of emergency.
@BATTLE
Rather like a good book changes your perspective.
I knew you'd catch on.
*ALARM*
And not a moment too soon.
Non. This is a good thing. I may yet be a positive influence on you.
The Morganas are attempting an ambush.
It's not very well executed.
@BATTLE
Are you still upset with me?
You insulted my intelligence at our book discussion the other day. What does that lead you to believe?
I wasn't insulting your intelligence.
"You're always like this when someone has the gall to disagree with you," you said. That doesn't sound like it was just about our Gatsby discussions, does it?
What would you like me to do?
What do you think?

Fields.MenuText: I'm sorry. Is that what you want to hear?
So, when you shout at me, you're being passionate. When I disagree with you I'm being hurtful. Does that seem fair?
We're still blaming the whole plot on Daisy?

Fields.DialogueText: Not with that tone of voice.
I shouted because I really, passionately dislike Daisy Buchanan and it got away from me. You said that I ignore dissenting voices and you can't trust my judgment. One is more personal than the other.
If you're not going to take responsibility for what you said, your apology is worthless.
*sigh*
I'm sorry. I clearly chose my words very poorly. I don't by any means think you're unreasonable or untrustworthy, and I never should have suggested otherwise.
Merci.
Non. I was walking along my deck reading Eliot when I spotted them on the horizon.
Ahem...I was walking along my deck reading Eliot-
All right, your peripheral vision's fine. Point made.
... That's it?
What's it?
Everything's okay?
I asked for a sincere apology and got one. Leave the ruminating to Gatsby.
You said I was, and I quote, "apparently incapable of listening."
That was a situational comment, not a blanket condemnation.
I had the most wonderful thought earlier.
You're in a happy mood. I thought you still might be upset from earlier.
You apologized. I've forgiven you and moved on.
Okay, then. Tell me about your wonderful thought.
Wouldn't it be great if we had a big party like Gatsby has in The Great Gatsby?

Fields.MenuText: What for?
That would be great! Those parties sounded fantastically over the top.
There would be a lot of work involved in that.

Fields.DialogueText: For fun, of course! It would break up the monotony between battles.
The best kind. One can either dive into the noise or blend into it. There's something for everyone in that.
I know, but the result would be great! Besides, cleaning helps me think.
What brought this idea on?
I was rereading some parts of The Great Gatsby and it came to mind.
Not only do you read books, but you reread them.
*ALARM*
Time to show off another one of your talents.
@BATTLE
The surprise isn't ruined for you the next time around?
Irrelevant. It's like reading a completely different book once you know where to look for dramatic irony, once you can retreat from a familiar narrative and start to pick at it.
You do all that with the same book and yet read so widely.
And quickly. I am a woman of many talents.
I'll have to cultivate that particular one myself.
All the better for our book club!
What are you reading now? I know that isn't for our book group, because I have that book.
Un autre Dorothy Sayers mystery. This one is called Gaudy Night.
It would seem you've taken a likening to mysteries recently.
I do love a good mystery novel every so often.
And I would venture to say Sayers writes good mystery novels, as this is the second of hers I've seen you reading.
You would be correct. On another subject, how is your reading for our group coming along?
It's going well. I've made quite a bit of headway.
Are you at the part where...
Don't say anything else! I don't want you to spoil anything for me.
*chuckles* I didn't realize you were enjoying it so much.

Fields.MenuText: Truth be told, I only just realized it myself.
That isn't it. I just don't want all of the time I've spent reading to go to waste by someone ruining the book.
Well, what isn't there to like about it?

Fields.DialogueText: Reading can surprise you that way. In fact, it ought to.
If I had my camera on me I'd capture the precise moment your expression betrayed you.
There are almost no truly bad books out there... simply unsuited readers.
I can't wait to discuss it with you once you're done.
I think I might even be able to keep up this time...
Save your speculation, Capitaine! We are joined by unwanted guests.
@BATTLE
Why the sad face?
I have this feeling that there is something missing in our book group.
What makes you say that?
During our last gathering, I was looking at the three of us, and it felt like we needed to add some... dissent.
I don't know that we need conflict for the sake of conflict. But, yeah, our conversations have definitely gotten shorter lately.
I knew the day would come when we all agreed on something. Do you have any ideas?

Fields.MenuText: We could play games together.
How about we bring food to the gatherings? I would like that.
Maybe we should change the location of where we meet.

Fields.DialogueText: I believe that may take away from our purpose, which is reading.
That's not what's missing, but it is a good idea. I'll keep it in mind for later.
And agree in a different place? Non, Capitaine, our problems stem from within.
I wish we had more variety, more worldviews. Our perspectives align too frequently for my liking.
Why not invite more people to the book group, then?
More people? I do suppose that might do the trick. I'm highly selective, though. It might take a while.
*ALARM*
I have every confidence that you're up to the task. Maybe someone will distinguish themselves against these Morganas.
@BATTLE
Still reading, I see.
Hold on one moment. I'm almost finished.
Il n'y a pas d'urgence. Take your time.
Hm... what? No!
I see you've made it to the ending.
That's it? That is how it ends?
I'm afraid so.

Fields.MenuText: How could the author do that?
With everything that happened throughout the book, I would have never expected it to end like that.
I'm speechless. How... why...

Fields.DialogueText: That is the freedom of being an author. You can do whatever you want.
Yes, the ending was entirely unexpected and completely caught me off guard.
I understand how you feel. Our discussions can be as much commiseration as debate.
Would you like a smoke? You look like you need one.
I think I need more than that. I don't know how I'll ever get over that ending.
That is the great power of books. They can mend the reader through catharsis. But they have the ability to break as well, through tragedy or anticlimax.
*ALARM*
You know, I honestly can't tell whether I'm grateful for the distraction.
@BATTLE
I for one appreciate a definitive ending now and again. Especially one I've blasted into being.
I spoke with our other book discussion member.
About adding more members to our group, I'm assuming.
Oui, and it seems we're all open to the idea.
Very good.
But there is one problem.
What's that?
How are we going to get more people to come to the group?
I don't think that's going to be an insuperable problem. Hm...
Maybe you could call a crew meeting and we could bring it up there.
I try to only use those meetings for important topics. Otherwise people won't take them seriously.
Or what if we created handouts to pass around?
That would require a lot of paper. Maybe if we simply went around and shared information.
Word spreads. You know how selective I am. Serious discussions need serious readers.
And it would require speaking with a lot of people, and that is something I would rather avoid. If possible.
Attendez. I think I have it.
What is it?
How about each of us find two people to bring to the next meeting?
That sounds manageable.
Plus, I wouldn't have to speak to many people. I'll go...
*ALARM*
It can wait.
@BATTLE
That makes sense. That rules out that idea.
You seemed okay with it at the showcase.
It is different when I can allow my work to speak for me.
You're up on the edge of the ship again. What do you see now?
Why not come up here and see for yourself?
Not all of us have your preternatural sense of balance, you know.
You'll be okay. Come on, I'll help you up.
Woah! Okay, okay, I'm up here. Now what?
Close your eyes and imagine you're somewhere else.
Okay, I can manage that.
What do you see?

Fields.MenuText: I see a rainbow that stretches out of a mountain top before falling back down to the ocean.
I see a street with lots of people walking each and every way, going to this stop or that one.
I see a large octopus swimming past me on the right, and a school of fish passing me on the left.

Fields.DialogueText: That sounds like a beautiful sight.
I can imagine it now. It reminds me of home.
Underwater? That's interesting. I've never imagined myself underwater, but now I'll have to try it.
How was that?
Merci, Capitaine. It was a pleasant experience to share. I hope it was for you as well.
It was certainly interesting. I would almost say I was in an altered state of consciousness.
Seeing the world through new eyes is not unlike rereading a book. Would you like to try again?
*ALARM*
After we take care of these Morganas.
Bien sûr.
@BATTLE
Your home must have been a comfortable place for all its bustle.
You don't look so well. How are you feeling?
Some digestive difficulties - I'll do you the favor of being unspecific. It must be something going around.
Oui. I saw a few of our new book group members looking queasy earlier as well.
You don't say?
By the way, thank you for the idea to bring food to our discussion, especially with all the new people we have had join.
Sure... although I thought you would have had the cooks make something for us instead of trying to whip it all up yourself.
I was going to, but I wanted to do something special. How did you like the food?

Fields.MenuText: It had a unique taste, that's for sure.
It was okay, but maybe have the cooks lend a hand next time.
It was so good. I can still taste it now.

Fields.DialogueText: You think it was like nothing you've ever tasted? Merci!
Thank you for being honest. I'll ask them for their help for the next meal.
Really? I have some more leftovers that I can give you.
I wish I could talk more, but I feel a wave of sickness coming on. If you'll excuse me...
I hope you feel better!
Oh, don't worry. As long as I have a few minutes of peace, I'll...
*ALARM*
... be rudely reminded that we're at war.
@BATTLE
I'm so happy!
The smile on your face certainly supports your statement. Why are you happy?
Because of how much our book group has grown! You know what the best part is now?

Fields.MenuText: That you're no longer cooking the food for the gatherings?
That there are lots of new people to talk to?
Tell me.

Fields.DialogueText: If you didn't like my cooking, all you had to do was say so.
That is part of why it's great, but not the main reason.
Avec plaisir!
The best part is now that we have more people, we have more books to share.
With more books, we'll need more copies for people to read.
Zurich will provide. Their morale stipend is notoriously flexible.
To be a fly on the wall for those budget meetings...
Oh, our requests are among the most benign. I'm not even trying to test their patience.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Meanwhile these Morganas continue to grate upon mine.
I was wondering if we could...
I know what we can do!
Huh?
Oh. Pardonnez-moi! Were you saying something?
Nothing important. What can we do?
For our book group. We can do a big project to celebrate our shared passion.
What did you have in mind?
I was thinking we could do a photography session where each person creates a shot that represents their favorite book.

Fields.MenuText: Did you come up with the idea just now?
I'm assuming you'll be taking the photographs.
Exercising the group's creative muscles? I like it.

Fields.DialogueText: Oui. It was peculiar. I wasn't even thinking of group project ideas. I was thinking back to my showcase and the format seemed perfectly adaptable.
Some, to be sure. But ideally I won't be the only one!
On an enclosed environment such as myself, who knows what they'll come up with?
Do you think the others will be interested in the project?
We'll know when we ask them. But, yes, I think so.
Great! I'll share it at our next meeting.
@BATTLE
Is this you signing us up for a photography course? Your public speaking must be improving.
... Perhaps I should be the one taking the pictures after all.
How did it go? Did everyone seem to like the idea?
Yes, I think everyone was excited for the photography project. I only saw smiles on everyone's faces.
That is a relief. Any idea what you're going to do for your photograph?
I'm planning on doing The Great Gatsby.
Really? The first book I gave you?
The very same. What are you planning on doing?
It's a surprise.

Fields.MenuText: But I told you mine.
Why ask me, if you knew you weren't going to tell me your idea?
That's not fair.

Fields.DialogueText: I know. The suspense is killing me. How devious of you.
I was curious, is all.
This from the person so concerned about spoiling endings?
You'll know what I chose the day of the photography event. I wouldn't dream of letting the surprise slip.
*ALARM*
Nothing like a skirmish to take my mind off of things...
@BATTLE
Curiosity. If it were always rewarded, there would be no need for art to fill in the blanks.
What a great turnout we have.
So many photographs I get to take! Stay right there. That's it.
*CLICK*
What exactly is it that you will be portraying in your photograph?
Gaudy Night! Can't you tell? Don't you think I look just like Harriet Vane?
Maybe if you put your hair up. You've been reading a lot of her books.
Oui - and I've grown to love Sayers as an author. Oh... and, Capitaine?
Yes, La Motte-Picquet?
Would you be willing to take my photograph once I've finished with everyone else?

Fields.MenuText: I would love to.
You'd trust me with that?
I think you'd know best how to capture yourself.

Fields.DialogueText: Merci! I knew you'd be up to the task. The exercise...no, still ill-fitting. The project? You'll like it, even if I cannot find the right word.
Maybe more. I've grown to appreciate your perspective over the course of our discussions. Here is one more way I may do so.
Every artist's first work is a self-portrait. I want to know what I look like through another's eyes.
Would this be part of the book club's project?
Non. I'd like this to be something more personal. The bond between captain and Belle will be the talk of generations to come.
What about the bond between friends?
Drowning in an ocean of ink. But there are some things shared only between the friends in question.
*ALARM*
Like chagrin at being interrupted by Morganas?
Non, that's all too common. Let us keep it from becoming universal.
@BATTLE
I wish I could... hm.
What? Oh, and also everyone I spoke with loved the photography event, La Motte-Picquet. You did a great job.
Vraiment? I'm glad. It would not have been good if I was the only one enjoying myself.

Fields.MenuText: What about me? I would have enjoyed the event as well.
Well, you can always count on me to enjoy your events, unless it involves food you've prepared.
You don't give yourself enough recognition.

Fields.DialogueText: Bien sûr. How could I forget you?
We will be revisiting that, Capitaine. Ideally with tasters who have been adequately compensated.
I prefer to let my work speak for me.
Okay, back to the original question. What do you wish you could do?
Oh... um, I was thinking about how it would be great if I could do another showcase with the photographs I took of the book group.
Why wouldn't you be able to do another one?
Well, I'd like to do it by the time we dock, but I don't know if that's too short of notice.
Nonsense.
Huh?
I've no doubt that, between the two of us, we can make it happen. Develop the photographs. As soon as they're ready, bring them to me. I'll take care of the rest.
*ALARM*
We will pick this up after the battle, Capitaine. You have saved my ambitions!
@BATTLE
Do you have the photographs?
Oui, I do. Voila!
Okay, great. Stay right here. I'll let you know when you can come in.
*ALARM*
Of course the Morganas would show up now of all times.
@BATTLE
Okay, La Motte-Picquet! We're ready for you!
What!? You... you remembered.
Yes, I did. Your very own Gatsby-style party!
This is amazing! And all the photographs from our event are hanging up. Thank you!
Of course, La Motte-Picquet. I'm glad you like it.
There is no way I couldn't like this. Everything looks right out of West Egg!
I have one more request of you, La Motte-Picquet.
What would that be?

Fields.MenuText: Dance with me?

Fields.DialogueText: Well, of course. It is a party, after all.

Fields.MenuText: Come and mingle?

Fields.DialogueText: For a change... I find myself in such a mood. Let us prosecute it to its end.

Fields.MenuText: Walk us through your photograph first.

Fields.DialogueText: Pour yourself a drink, Capitaine. I've put quite a lot of thought into this...
